text: a constitutional rule over government
plans to suspend Parliament I think
people should be on the streets
it's dictatorship smash-and-grab on our
democracy Queen has given her approval
[Music]
what's happened is that the government
has asked the Queen to suspend
Parliament that means MPs won't sit here
at Westminster from the 10th of
September which is just a week after
they come back from their summer break
next week until the 14th of October the
Prime Minister says the reason for this
is so that the government can hold a
Queen's speech that usually happens once
a year and it's an opportunity for the
government to set out its plans for the
year ahead and Parliament is normally
suspended before a Queen's Speech we
need new legislation we've got to be
bringing forward new and important bills
and that's why we are going to have a
Queen's speech and we're going to do it
on October the 14th
because it's happening so close to the
brexit deadline of October the 31st this
is caused a huge rau because MPs who
want to avoid a No Deal brexit say it's
an abuse of the government's power and
they see it as a way to try to shut down
the discussion and debate that they want
to have in Parliament and their attempts
to try to force the government into
asking for an extension to the brexit
process or bringing the government down
with a vote of no-confidence what the
Prime Minister's doing is a sort of
smash and grab on our democracy in order
to force through a No Deal exit from the
European Union what's he so afraid of
that he needs to suspend Parliament to
prevent Parliament discussing these
matters like some kind of 10-point
dictator it frankly is not acceptable
and if MPs don't stop it then it is no
exaggeration it is not hyperbole to see
this is the D any semblance of UK
parliamentary democracy absolutely
dies suspending Parliament is something
the government has the power to do at
any time although it's officially
authorized by the Queen and there's no
clear way for MPs who aren't happy about
it to stop it broadly there are three
options now the first is to legislate
but as we've discussed that's really
difficult in terms of the timing the
second is to try to bring the courts
into it the third is to try and no
confidence vote in the Prime Minister
which could lead to an election
this decision to suspend Parliament
doesn't mean that there's definitely
going to be a general election but
there's lots of speculation that one
could be held this autumn either if the
government loses a vote of no-confidence
or if the Prime Minister decides one is
needed and two-thirds of MPs back that
decision
